overview.title: What it is
overview.text: Oxytocin is a bioactive compound discussed in research and/or clinical contexts. This entry summarizes what it is, what it is studied for, and key evidence limitations without providing protocols.

developmental_risk_block.text: Developmental risk is flagged due to limited adolescent data and uncertain long-term effects. Endocrine, growth, neurodevelopmental, and metabolic setpoints may be sensitive to perturbation. This section is descriptive only; uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged.

changelog.detail: Generated from queue ingestion (Phase 6). Requires human-authored, evidence-bounded content.

meta.notes_seed: FDA-approved oxytocin (Rx) uterotonic; include only label-level indications; no protocols.

practical.bottom_line: Oxytocin is a human hormone used clinically in specific obstetric settings. In non-clinical markets it is discussed for social bonding and mood effects, but the biggest risks are inappropriate use, contraindicated medical situations, and lack of supervision.
benefits: Social bonding and connection interest in some communities
Stress and mood support interest in some communities
Clinical relevance in obstetric care contexts
side_effects_serious: Chest pain, fainting, or severe shortness of breath
who_should_be_cautious: Postpartum complications or significant gynecologic history
